repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This change accepts both two and three argument versions for `__pow__`, `__rpow__` and `__ipow__`.

For the two arg versions it raises an exception if three arguments are passed (although accepts a third argument of 'None' since this is what Python does by default).

For the three arg versions it allows a default argument of None to be set (but no other default arguments).

One deviation from Python:

```
class C:
  def __pow__(a, b, c):
    return a, b, c
```

will raise `TypeError: C.__pow__() missing 1 required positional argument: 'c'`
for all of
```
C()**2
pow(C(), 2)
pow(C(), 2, None)
```

(i.e. it just looks to see if None has been passed and treats that are 2 args only).

I haven't done this - it seems like a backwards compatibility mistake for Cython. Although it would be possible.

I haven't tied any of this to `c_api_binop_methods`. I think it's independent, although if we did want to reject None on the three argument power function, we could use that directive.

Fixes #5160

comment_data.body: An `#error` seems unhelpful here. It seems ok to implement the method, even if it doesn't work in Py<3.8. The usual effect would just be less efficient code, most of the time. I'd rather keep the slot empty in older versions (it's effectively not implemented). You'd probably still get a C compiler warning that the function is unused, which seems enough to make users aware that it's … not being used. We could also mention this shortcoming in the special method docs.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4521,6 +4532,32 @@ def generate_argument_type_tests(self, code):
                                           arg.type.is_buffer or
                                           arg.type.is_memoryviewslice):
                 self.generate_arg_none_check(arg, code)
+        if self.target.entry.is_special:
+            for n in reversed(range(len(self.args), self.signature.max_num_fixed_args())):
+                # for special functions with optional args (e.g. power which can
+                # take 2 or 3 args), unused args are None since this is what the
+                # compilers sets
+                if self.target.entry.name == "__ipow__":
+                    # Bug in Python < 3.8 - __ipow__ is used as a binary function
+                    # and attempts to access the third argument will always fail
+                    code.putln("#if PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x03080000")
+                code.putln("if (unlikely(unused_arg_%s != Py_None)) {" % n)
+                code.putln(
+                    'PyErr_SetString(PyExc_TypeError, '
+                    '"%s() takes %s arguments but %s were given");' % (
+                        self.target.entry.qualified_name, self.signature.max_num_fixed_args(), n))
+                code.putln("%s;" % code.error_goto(self.pos))
+                code.putln("}")
+                if self.target.entry.name == "__ipow__":
+                    code.putln("#endif /*PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x03080000*/")
+            if self.target.entry.name == "__ipow__" and len(self.args) != 2:
+                # It's basically impossible to safely support it:
+                # Class().__ipow__(1) is guarranteed to crash.
+                # therefore, just emit a C error as the safest thing to do.
+                code.putln("#if PY_VERSION_HEX < 0x03080000")
+                code.putln('#error "%s: 3-argument %s cannot be used in Python<3.8"' % (
+                            format_position(self.pos), self.target.entry.qualified_name))
+                code.putln('#endif')

comment_data.body:
On a second look, I agree that an `#error` seems like over-kill.

I've replaced it with an exception on call. That seems like the best way to give a clear explanation to the user. The crash is only is you try to access the third argument, so raising an exception is safe.

The other option might be runtime warning +  return `NotImplemented` - that'd fall back to `__pow__` as you say mostly so might be better.

+                code.putln("%s;" % code.error_goto(self.pos))
+                code.putln("}")

+            if self.target.entry.name == "__ipow__" and len(self.args) != 2:
+                # It's basically impossible to safely support it:

+                code.putln('#endif')

comment_data.body: Thinking about it more, not implemented would be better. I'll come back to this later... Marking as draft just so it doesn't get merged before then

comment_data.body:
I had another look at it:
* not assigning the type slot is really hard - you just don't have the right information available when the code is generated.
* Runtime warning + NotImplemented doesn't fall back to `__pow__`.
* Therefore, I think raising an error is as good a solution as anything. Especially since this is really rare - the only way to call a 3-arg `__ipow__` is from a C API function and it isn't possible directly from Python. Therefore I don't think it's worth wasting too much more time on.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4521,6 +4532,32 @@ def generate_argument_type_tests(self, code):
                                           arg.type.is_buffer or
                                           arg.type.is_memoryviewslice):

+                # for special functions with optional args (e.g. power which can
+                # take 2 or 3 args), unused args are None since this is what the
+                # compilers sets
+                if self.target.entry.name == "__ipow__":

+                    # and attempts to access the third argument will always fail
+                    code.putln("#if PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x03080000")
+                code.putln("if (unlikely(unused_arg_%s != Py_None)) {" % n)
+                code.putln(
+                    'PyErr_SetString(PyExc_TypeError, '
+                    '"%s() takes %s arguments but %s were given");' % (

+                code.putln("%s;" % code.error_goto(self.pos))
+                code.putln("}")
+                if self.target.entry.name == "__ipow__":
+                    code.putln("#endif /*PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x03080000*/")
+            if self.target.entry.name == "__ipow__" and len(self.args) != 2:
+                # It's basically impossible to safely support it:
+                # Class().__ipow__(1) is guarranteed to crash.
+                # therefore, just emit a C error as the safest thing to do.
+                code.putln("#if PY_VERSION_HEX < 0x03080000")
+                code.putln('#error "%s: 3-argument %s cannot be used in Python<3.8"' % (
+                            format_position(self.pos), self.target.entry.qualified_name))
+                code.putln('#endif')

commit.message:
Support 2 and 3 arg __[ri]pow__

This change accepts both two and three argument versions
for __pow__ and __ipow__.

For the two arg versions it raises an exception if three
arguments are passed (although accepts a third argument of
'None' since this is what Python does by default).

For the three arg versions it allows a default argument of None
to be set (but no other default arguments).

One deviation from Python:

```
class C:
  def __pow__(a, b, c):
    return a, b, c
```

will raise `TypeError: C.__pow__() missing 1 required positional
argument: 'c'`
for all of
```
C()**2
pow(C(), 2)
pow(C(), 2, None)
```

(i.e. it just looks to see if None has been passed and treats
that are 2 args only).

I haven't done this - it seems like a backwards compatibility
mistake for Cython. Although it would be possible.

I haven't tied any of this to `c_api_binop_methods`. I think it's
independent, although if we did want to reject None on the three
argument power function, we could use that directive.

commit.message:
Replace compile error with runtime error

and add docs

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Support 2 and 3 arg __[ri]pow__
